valeursRefPathologies: Diaphragm thickness and dysfunction:
A difference between left and right hemidiaphragm of 0.33 cm is abnormal [3].
A thickness at FRC < 0.2 cm AND thickening < 20% are indicative of diaphragmatic paralysis [8].
In chronic diaphragmatic paralysis, diaphragm thickness is < 0.2 cm, while in acute diaphragmatic paralysis, thickness may not necessarily be affected [9].
Mechanical ventilator weaning in intensive care:
Thickening fraction threshold values, measured at the right hemidiaphragm, for successful extubation:
> 36% with sensitivity 0.82, specificity 0.88, positive predictive value 0.92 and negative predictive value 0.75 [10]
≥ 26% with sensitivity 0.96, specificity 0.68, positive predictive value 0.89 and negative predictive value 0.86 [11]
Relationship between diaphragm thickness and extubation success, from Canadian critical care [12]:
After 4 days of mechanical ventilation, 40% of ventilated patients show decreased diaphragm thickness, and consequently, decreased ventilator weaning success rate [8].
Conversely, some ventilated patients show increased diaphragm thickness, and consequently, decreased ventilator weaning success rate [12].
The increase in diaphragm thickness during ventilation has not yet been explained, but high inspiratory effort was associated with increased diaphragm thickness [12].
Other studies have noted a linear relationship between diaphragm thickness and ventilator weaning success [8].
Elastography (kPa) in COPD:
FRC: 33.25 ± 10.76, TLC: 35.83 ± 8.64 [7]
Pre-operative screening for cardiac surgery:
A thickening fraction < 38.1% is a predictive factor for post-operative pulmonary complications [13].

valeursRefPathologies: Excursion: Paralysis/Diaphragmatic Dysfunction
At tidal volume, in the presence of paralysis, there is either no movement or paradoxical movement (cranial) ≤ 0.5cm of the affected hemidiaphragm [8].
During deep breathing (FRC → TLC), paradoxical movement (cranial) ≥ 0.1cm of the affected hemidiaphragm may be observed [8].
The healthy hemidiaphragm in a subject with diaphragmatic paralysis may have increased excursion compared to the normative value of a control patient [8].

text: The diaphragm is the main muscle of respiration. Diaphragm contraction can be involuntary or voluntary, and its innervation comes from the phrenic nerve (C3-C4-C5). The diaphragm is primarily composed of a musculoaponeurotic partition separating the thorax from the abdomen with a dome-like appearance concave downward. It originates from the phrenic center of the diaphragm, composed of two asymmetric domes whose peaks, higher on the right, are at the level of the 4th or 5th intercostal space and on the left at the level of the 5th or 6th intercostal space. It then inserts on the xiphoid process, the internal surfaces of the 7th to 12th costal cartilages, the medial and lateral borders of the arcuate ligament of the diaphragm, and from the 1st to 3rd lumbar vertebrae.

There is a muscular portion of the diaphragm that is in contact with the rib cage; this portion is called the zone of apposition (ZOA). The ZOA is located between the 8th and 10th intercostal spaces, between the midaxillary line and the anterior axillary line. The upper part of the diaphragm is in contact with the pleura and pericardium while the lower part is attached to the peritoneum. Under the right hemidiaphragm, we find the liver and right kidney, and under the left hemidiaphragm, we find the stomach, spleen, colic angle, and left kidney.

text: Monitoring recovery of diaphragmatic function [8]
Scoliosis can be a source of diaphragmatic dysfunction and respiratory function impairment [20].
Diaphragmatic paralysis can be iatrogenic or neurological (stroke, spinal cord injury, etc.) [14].
Biofeedback can be used in the treatment of diaphragmatic dysfunction [20].
